Laws ch. 186 (landlord-tenant.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment that guarantees a tenant’s right to use and enjoy the leased premises without substantial interference by the landlord or conditions attributable to the landlord.

Commonwealth v. Alcoholic Beverages Cont.raw_text: Commonwealth v. Alcoholic Beverages Control Comm’n, 430 Mass. 796 (1999) (general principles of statutory construction).
Commonwealth v. Alcoholic Beverages Cont.proposition: Commonwealth v. Alcoholic Beverages Control Comm’n, 430 Mass. 796 (1999) (general principles of statutory construction).
Commonwealth v. Alcoholic Beverages Cont.case_name: Ruggerio Ambulance Service, Inc. v. National Grange Mutual Insurance
Commonwealth v. Alcoholic Beverages Cont.support_reasoning: The cited opinion is Ruggerio Ambulance Service v. National Grange, not Commonwealth v. Alcoholic Beverages Control Comm’n, and it deals with insurance coverage (duty to defend and indemnify), not general principles of statutory construction. The text concerns contract/insurance-policy interpretation, causation, and scope of automobile coverage, without articulating broader canons of statutory construction or citing Alcoholic Beverages Control Comm’n at all. Therefore it does not support the proposition as described.
Commonwealth v. Alcoholic Beverages Cont.relevant_excerpt: “The responsibility of construing the language of an insurance contract is a question of law for the trial judge, and then for the reviewing court.” Cody v. Connecticut Gen. Life Ins. Co., 387 Mass. 142, 146 (1982). We must determine whether the decedent’s death is sufficiently related to the ambulance’s accident to mandate coverage by the automobile policy and to trigger National Grange’s duty to indemnify.

McNally v. Gaston, 395 Mass. 111 (1985).raw_text: McNally v. Gaston, 395 Mass. 111 (1985) (tenancy and landlord duties).
McNally v. Gaston, 395 Mass. 111 (1985).proposition: McNally v. Gaston, 395 Mass. 111 (1985) (tenancy and landlord duties).
McNally v. Gaston, 395 Mass. 111 (1985).case_name: Cruz v. Commissioner of Public Welfare
McNally v. Gaston, 395 Mass. 111 (1985).support_reasoning: The proposition describes McNally v. Gaston as a case about tenancy and landlord duties, but the provided opinion is a Medicaid/immigration eligibility case (involving an alien’s eligibility for medical assistance and conformity of state regulations with federal Medicaid rules). It does not address landlord-tenant law, tenancies, or landlord duties. Therefore, this opinion does not support the stated proposition and appears to be a miscitation or wrong case text for that citation.
McNally v. Gaston, 395 Mass. 111 (1985).relevant_excerpt: “This appeal involves a challenge to a regulation of the Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare that precludes certain nonimmigrant aliens from receiving medical assistance benefits (medicaid). … The plaintiff … applied for medicaid in 1982. The Department of Public Welfare (Department) denied her application because the plaintiff did not meet the eligibility requirements of 106 Code Mass. Regs. § 503.200 (1981).”

Driscoll v. Fellsway Dev. Corp., 427 Mas.raw_text: Driscoll v. Fellsway Dev. Corp., 427 Mass. 22 (1998) (tenant remedies for defective premises).
Driscoll v. Fellsway Dev. Corp., 427 Mas.proposition: Driscoll v. Fellsway Dev. Corp., 427 Mass. 22 (1998) (tenant remedies for defective premises).
Driscoll v. Fellsway Dev. Corp., 427 Mas.support_reasoning: The claimed proposition describes Driscoll as a case about tenant remedies for defective premises, but this opinion concerns probation surrender procedures and credit for pretrial confinement under Massachusetts sentencing statutes. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, habitability, or remedies for defective rental premises. Therefore, citing this case for tenant remedies is inaccurate and not supported by the opinion’s subject matter or holdings.
Driscoll v. Fellsway Dev. Corp., 427 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The defendant next contends that he should have received credit against his sentence on the revoked probation for the amount of time he served while awaiting trial for the prior, unrelated armed robbery charge, pursuant to G. L. c. 127, § 129B, and G. L. c. 279, § 33A. He claims that, because he was acquitted of the robbery charge, the 410 days he spent awaiting trial was essentially “dead time” for which he is entitled credit.

Smith v. Thompson, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 561.raw_text: Smith v. Thompson, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 561 (1981) (quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction principles).
Smith v. Thompson, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 561.proposition: Smith v. Thompson, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 561 (1981) (quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction principles).
Smith v. Thompson, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 561.support_reasoning: This opinion is a contract-interpretation and civil procedure (Rule 56(f)) case involving termination of a sublease upon termination of an overlease through purchase; it does not discuss quiet enjoyment or constructive eviction. The court’s analysis is limited to whether the words “for any cause” in the sublease include voluntary termination by purchase and whether additional discovery was warranted. There is no treatment of landlord interference with possession, breach of covenant of quiet enjoyment, or conditions constituting constructive eviction.
Smith v. Thompson, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 561.relevant_excerpt: “In such event the trial judge was correct in ruling that the sublease is to terminate on termination of the Westby lease whatever be the cause of such termination, including termination by purchase.… Thus, nothing was presented to the judge which suggested that the interpretation of the words ‘for any cause’ would be affected by extrinsic evidence, or that the information sought would have raised a material factual question.”

Fogarty v. Rosen, 329 Mass. 617 (1952) (.raw_text: Fogarty v. Rosen, 329 Mass. 617 (1952) (landlord obligations and tenant remedies).
Fogarty v. Rosen, 329 Mass. 617 (1952) (.proposition: Fogarty v. Rosen, 329 Mass. 617 (1952) (landlord obligations and tenant remedies).
Fogarty v. Rosen, 329 Mass. 617 (1952) (.case_name: Smith v. August A. Busch Co. of Massachusetts, Inc.
Fogarty v. Rosen, 329 Mass. 617 (1952) (.support_reasoning: The proposition is very general and simply labels the case as concerning landlord obligations and tenant remedies. Fogarty v. Rosen squarely addresses premises-liability duties owed by an occupier of land (a restaurant) to business visitors and the effect of using an independent contractor, which are core aspects of a landholder’s obligations and an injured visitor’s remedies. Although the opinion is framed as storekeeper–customer rather than classic landlord–tenant, it is reasonably accurate to cite it for general premises obligations and remedies.
Fogarty v. Rosen, 329 Mass. 617 (1952) (.relevant_excerpt: If we assume that Busch was acting as an independent contractor and that the work in which it was engaged was not inherently dangerous... the defendant Ort was not thereby excused from the duty which it owed the plaintiff, a customer, of using proper care to keep its premises in a reasonably safe condition for his use according to the invitation or of warning him of the dangers of which he as an ordinarily intelligent person might not be expected to know and which were either known or ought to have been known to this defendant.

Nardini v. O\u2019Neill, 4 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Nardini v. O’Neill, 4 Mass. App. Ct. 195 (1976) (repair obligations and constructive eviction).
Nardini v. O\u2019Neill, 4 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Nardini v. O’Neill, 4 Mass. App. Ct. 195 (1976) (repair obligations and constructive eviction).
Nardini v. O\u2019Neill, 4 Mass. App. Ct.case_name: School Committee of Leominster v. Gallagher
Nardini v. O\u2019Neill, 4 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts labor/arbitration case about salary schedules and the scope of an arbitrator’s authority under a teachers’ collective bargaining agreement. It does not discuss landlord‑tenant law, repair obligations, or constructive eviction. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a proposition concerning repair obligations and constructive eviction, and appears to be a miscitation or incorrect parenthetical description.
Nardini v. O\u2019Neill, 4 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A policy of paying a higher rate to an entering teacher who possesses both an academic degree and a vocational certification may amount to nothing more than the recognition of practical necessity. A policy of refusing to pay the same higher rate to a present member of the system who adds a vocational certification to his academic degree is the practical equivalent of a policy of paying the present member as little as possible. … It is not an educational policy of the type which a school committee can properly refuse to submit to the collective bargaining process or refuse to delegate to an arbitrator for determination by him.”

Shea v. Boston, 374 Mass. 106 (1978) (ha.raw_text: Shea v. Boston, 374 Mass. 106 (1978) (habitability and municipal enforcement).
Shea v. Boston, 374 Mass. 106 (1978) (ha.proposition: Shea v. Boston, 374 Mass. 106 (1978) (habitability and municipal enforcement).
Shea v. Boston, 374 Mass. 106 (1978) (ha.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Shea v. Boston, 374 Mass. 106 (1978), nor does it address issues of habitability or municipal enforcement. Instead, it concerns interpretation of the Babson will and the testator’s intent regarding use of the federal estate tax marital deduction and allocation of estate/inheritance taxes. Therefore, this text does not support any proposition about habitability or municipal enforcement attributed to Shea v. Boston.
Shea v. Boston, 374 Mass. 106 (1978) (ha.relevant_excerpt: “This is an action brought under G. L. c. 231A by the executors of the will of Paul T. Babson seeking declarations of the testator’s intent with respect to those provisions of his will which concern the Federal estate tax marital deduction and which affect the amount of such tax… On the merits, we hold that articles Seventh, Twelfth, and Eighteenth of the Babson will evidence an intent to receive the maximum possible benefit of the estate tax marital deduction.”

Lombard v. Malden, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 299.raw_text: Lombard v. Malden, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 299 (1996) (tenant’s remedies in housing cases).
Lombard v. Malden, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 299.proposition: Lombard v. Malden, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 299 (1996) (tenant’s remedies in housing cases).
Lombard v. Malden, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 299.support_reasoning: The proposition describes Lombard v. Malden as a case about tenant’s remedies in housing matters, but the quoted opinion is a criminal case involving double jeopardy, mistrial, and ineffective assistance of counsel in a firearms prosecution. It does not concern landlord-tenant law, housing conditions, or tenant remedies, so it cannot support that proposition. The citation is therefore inaccurate or refers to a different Lombard case.
Lombard v. Malden, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 299.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was convicted at a bench trial of unlawful possession of a firearm and unlawful possession of ammunition. He was found not guilty of possession of an altered firearm. He appealed to the jury-of-six session. ... The Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution provides, in part, “nor shall any person be subject for the same offence to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb.” ... A mistrial that is declared over the defendant’s objection will not bar a second trial whenever it is the trial judge’s opinion that ... there is a manifest necessity for the [declaration of a mistrial]...

Hammar v. Wright, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 60 (.proposition: Hammar v. Wright, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 60 (1983) (interference with quiet enjoyment).
Hammar v. Wright, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 60 (.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Hammar v. Wright at all; it is a criminal case involving Commonwealth v. Carlson concerning improper police contact with a represented defendant and related suppression/dismissal issues. The opinion does not mention landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or interference with quiet enjoyment, and therefore cannot support any proposition about interference with quiet enjoyment. The citation to Hammar v. Wright is simply misidentified or incorrect for this text.
Hammar v. Wright, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 60 (.relevant_excerpt: The defendant contends that the complaints on which he was convicted should have been dismissed pursuant to his pretrial motion which sought their dismissal on the ground that officers of the Massachusetts State police had engaged in improper conduct which abridged his Federal and State constitutional rights. We affirm the judgments of conviction.
